subject: Languages
title: The Phoenician Alphabet: Mother of All Alphabets
description: A quick, practical guide to The Phoenician Alphabet: Mother of All Alphabets.

hook.text: Nearly every alphabet on Earth descends from one created by traders in modern-day Lebanon around 1050 BCE.

buildup.text: The Phoenicians were seafaring merchants who needed a simple system anyone could learn quickly.

discovery.text: Their genius: one symbol per consonant sound. Just 22 letters could write any word.

twist.text: The Phoenician alphabet had no vowels â€” readers had to figure them out from context.

climax.text: From Phoenician came Greek, Latin, Arabic, Hebrew, and nearly every alphabet used today.

punchline.text: Merchants who wanted simpler bookkeeping gave the world every alphabet it has.

quiz.question: What was revolutionary about the Phoenician alphabet?
options: It used one symbol per consonant, making it easy to learn
It included pictures for every word
It was the first to use vowels
